title: 'HIV infections could rise': Scientist warns aid halt could undo past gains
text:
Dr Glenda Gray, a leading global authority on HIV prevention, tells TRT World that US President Trump's halt on USAID has created uncertainty and confusion for those relying on antiretroviral treatments in South Africa and beyond.
Dr Glenda Gray, a leading global authority on HIV prevention, tells TRT World that US President Trump's halt on USAID has created uncertainty and confusion for those relying on antiretroviral treatments in South Africa and beyond.Dr Glenda Gray, a leading expert in HIV research at Wits University in South Africa , is internationally renowned for her pioneering work in preventing the transmission of HIV from infected mothers to their newborns.
In a country where 5.5 million people rely on antiretroviral treatment, the funding uncertainty has become a massive concern. Recently, a federal judge in the US ruled that the Trump administration must temporarily lift the funding freeze., the uncertainty is far from over. There's still the looming fear that without continued support, patients may miss treatment, HIV infection rates may rise, and ultimately, more lives could be lost.
There are real concerns that if the freeze on funding continues, infections could rise not just in South Africa but across other affected countries as well. SB — If the US president's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief saves millions of lives, why is South Africa still left in limbo?At this moment, it appears that the stop-work order remains in place for South Africa, despite the court ruling lifting the USAID funding freeze.
However, this funding has largely been limited to the pre-clinical stage, falling far short of what is needed to conduct large-scale clinical trials.
